The rain fell on St Helens with a grim, percussive determination. It wasn't cleansing or poetic rain; it was the sort that seeped into brickwork and darkened the soul, turning the world outside Cassandra Blackwood’s window into a smear of grey slate roofs and glistening tarmac. From her vantage point in the spare bedroom of the terraced house she’d inherited, the world looked like a problem that had been left to fester. A badly designed system, full of bugs and redundancies. The noise of it all, even muted by double-glazing, was a constant irritant. A car horn, too aggressive. The shrill, pointless laughter of teenagers sheltering under a bus stop. The distant, rhythmic thud from a neighbour's stereo. It was all just... inefficient data.

Cassie adjusted the waveform on her monitor. A glowing green sine wave, pulsing with a gentle, almost biological rhythm. To anyone else, it was just a pattern. A sound, if converted, that would be a low, barely audible hum interspersed with a specific, non-repeating sequence of clicks. To Cassie, it was the key. It was the off-switch. She looked from the screen to the houses opposite. Number 42 and number 44. The Yates family and the Crompton family. For six months, their feud had been the street’s primary source of low-level entertainment. A war waged over the territorial integrity of a privet hedge. There had been shouting, passive-aggressive wheelie bin placements, and a truly spectacular incident involving a hosepipe and an open kitchen window.

Three days ago, Cassie had aimed a small, discreetly modified parabolic dish at their adjoining gardens and broadcast the hum. The silence since had been absolute. It wasn't a truce. A truce was an agreement, a fragile pause in hostilities, pregnant with the threat of resumption. This was different. This was… a deletion. Yesterday, Mrs. Yates had been reversing her Fiat Panda out of her drive and Mr. Crompton had been bringing in his recycling. He had paused, holding the blue bin, and looked directly at her car as it blocked his path. Cassie had watched, her breath held not in suspense but in academic curiosity. It was the perfect test condition. In the old paradigm, this moment would have ignited at least a withering glare, possibly a muttered curse. Instead, Mr. Crompton had simply stood there, his expression a perfect blank. He didn't look patient. He didn't look annoyed. He looked like a man waiting for a train that he had no particular feelings about catching. When Mrs. Yates had finally driven off, he had simply continued on his way. The conflict hadn't been resolved. It had been rendered irrelevant. The neural pathways that fired in defence of territory, of pride, of tribal affiliation to ‘House Crompton,’ had been… bypassed.

A faint smile, a practiced muscular arrangement she’d perfected in the mirror, touched Cassie’s lips. It worked. Of course, it worked. The logic was sound. Human conflict wasn’t a matter of philosophy or morality. It was a glitch in the wetware. A primitive survival instinct, scaled up to civilizational levels, that was no longer fit for purpose. War, politics, religion—it was all just the privet hedge writ large. People drawing lines in the sand and getting violently, irrationally angry when someone else stepped over them. Her signal didn't make people good. It didn't make them love each other. It just snipped the thread of blind, neurological investment in the 'us' versus 'them' equation. It induced a state of profound, unshakable apathy towards large-scale group identity. It was a cure.

Her phone buzzed on the desk, rattling against a stray capacitor. The screen lit up with a picture of a smiling, red-headed woman squinting into the sun. LEA. The only variable Cassie permitted herself. Leanne was a system running on entirely different code, one Cassie had long ago decided it was more efficient to accommodate than to try and understand. She let it buzz a second time before answering, softening her voice into the pre-recorded cadence of 'concerned friend.'

"Alright, Lea?"

"Alright, our kid? You're alive then," Leanne's voice crackled through, warm and tangible, smelling faintly of chip spice and hairspray. "I was gonna send a search party. Thought you might have finally fused yourself to one of your circuit boards."

"Just been busy," Cassie said, swivelling her chair to face the wall. It was easier to perform without the visual distraction of her work. "You know how it is."

"No, Cassie, I really don't. Normal people get busy with work, or decorating, or watching the entire box set of something trashy. You get busy looking like you're trying to contact another dimension from your back bedroom. Mum said she saw your light on at 4 a.m. again."

"I was just working through a problem." A small, insignificant problem. The final sequencing for global broadcast. How to piggyback the signal onto every mobile phone mast, every television satellite, every radio wave on the planet simultaneously. A matter of logistics, not theory.

"Is it that... project? The peace thing?" Leanne's voice was gentle, the way you’d talk to someone convinced they were knitting a jumper for a unicorn. She was the only person Cassie had ever told, and even then, only in the vaguest, most metaphorical terms. 'A way to make the background noise stop,' she'd called it. Lea, bless her illogical, compassionate heart, had assumed she was talking about a new form of meditation app.

"Something like that," Cassie hedged.

"Well, come up for air, will you? We're going The Swan tonight. Me, Chloe, and Sarah. For Sarah's birthday. You've got to come. You can't miss it."

Cassie's mind processed the request. Social gathering. Loud music. Inefficient communication protocols requiring shouting. High probability of pointless emotional displays. Minimum two hours of feigning interest in conversations about relationships and television programmes. The logical answer was no. But her Leanne-protocol dictated otherwise. Isolation bred suspicion. Regular, scheduled social interaction was a necessary component of her camouflage.

"Yeah, sound. What time?" she asked, the words feeling like foreign objects in her mouth.

"Eight. And wear something other than that grey jumper that's got solder on the sleeve. Try and look like you're not building a death ray."

"It's not a death ray," Cassie said, a genuine flicker of irritation breaking through the performance. The imprecision was galling. "It's the opposite of a death ray."

"Whatever, weirdo. Just be there. Eight o'clock. Don't be late."

The line went dead. Cassie placed the phone back on the desk. The Swan. She could already feel the headache. Still, it was a necessary sacrifice. Leanne was her firewall. The one person whose unquestioning loyalty and social normality shielded Cassie from the kind of scrutiny she couldn't afford. As long as 'Cassie-from-down-the-road-who's-a-bit-odd-but-sound-really' existed in the local consciousness, the architect of global neurological restructuring could work undisturbed.

She turned back to her screens. On one, a news feed scrolled relentlessly. A border dispute in a country she'd never visit. Politicians shouting over each other in a parliament building. Pundits with angry, certain faces. Riots over a flag. All of it so loud. So pointless. So… messy. Like children screaming in a supermarket. You didn't reason with them. You didn't engage with their tantrum. You found a way to make it stop.

The decision coalesced, not as a moment of dramatic epiphany, but as a simple, logical conclusion. The tests were complete. The delivery system was designed. The constant, low-level irritation had finally surpassed the threshold of tolerance. She wasn't doing it for them. She was doing it for her. She wanted some peace and quiet.

She opened a new file, a complex string of code that would, when executed, begin a domino-like cascade, hijacking servers and uplinks across the globe. The Swan at eight. That gave her a few hours. A few more hours of the old world, the loud world. She began to type, her fingers moving with an unnatural speed and precision. The code was elegant, beautiful in its ruthless efficiency. And as she worked, the low, pulsing hum from her test speakers filled the small, grey room, a promise of the silence to come. A silence she would impose on everyone, for everyone's good. But mostly for hers. She looked at the completed code, the culmination of years of secret, obsessive work. A single 'Enter' key press was all that stood between the world as it was and the world as it should be. The world as she had designed it. Calm. Quiet. Logical. She minimized the window. First, The Swan. One last performance. One last tour of the zoo before she put all the animals to sleep.Seven o’clock found her standing in front of the wardrobe in her bedroom, a room as spartan as her lab was cluttered. The choice of clothing was a tactical one. The grey jumper with the solder burn was her default state, her true skin. Tonight required a costume. She selected a plain black top and dark jeans, an outfit calculated to be unremarkable, to fade into the background chatter of a pub on a Friday night. Looking in the mirror was like checking the calibration of a tool. She practiced her social smile again. The muscles felt stiff, unused. The expression didn't reach her eyes, but in the low, forgiving light of a crowded pub, it would pass inspection. The whole ritual felt like a profound waste of processing power.

The walk to The Swan was only ten minutes, but it was ten minutes of unfiltered, irritating data. The rain had eased to a persistent, greasy drizzle that clung to her hair and face. Each passing car threw up a spray of filthy water, a chaotic, unpredictable variable she had to sidestep. The world was a sequence of minor assaults. She passed a house where a domestic argument was leaking through a steamed-up window, the angry, jagged waveforms of the voices a familiar, ugly pattern. Further on, a group of men were laughing, a loud, braying sound that seemed to serve no purpose other than to occupy acoustic space. She felt a deep, weary impatience. It was like living inside a computer that was perpetually overheating, its fans screaming, its processes crashing. The urge to just pull the plug was immense.

The Swan was an assault on every sense. She pushed open the heavy, condensation-slicked door and a wall of heat, noise, and the cloying smell of stale beer and cheap perfume hit her. The place was heaving, a chaotic mass of bodies shouting to be heard over a sound system that was distorting a pop song into a rhythmic shriek. To Cassie, it looked like a petri dish of flawed programming. Hundreds of individual wetware systems, all running their chaotic, ego-driven subroutines, colliding and interacting with zero overarching logic. She scanned the crowd, her gaze sweeping through the bodies with the detached efficiency of a facial recognition program, looking for the familiar splash of Leanne’s red hair.

She spotted them crammed into a booth near the back, a small island of relative calm in the churning sea of people. Leanne was waving, her smile a beacon of genuine, un-programmed warmth that Cassie found both baffling and useful. Sarah, the birthday girl, was laughing, her head thrown back, while Chloe was gesticulating wildly, telling a story that was clearly reaching its punchline. As Cassie threaded her way through the throng, apologising without meaning it as she bumped into people, she felt a profound sense of alienation. She was a biologist visiting an aviary, observing the brightly coloured, noisy creatures, understanding their behaviours on a mechanical level but feeling no kinship, no shared experience. This was the world she was about to save from itself, and it didn't even know it was sick.

"There she is! Thought you'd got lost in a wormhole!" Leanne shouted over the din as Cassie slid onto the worn vinyl of the booth. A lukewarm glass of prosecco was immediately thrust into her hand. "Happy birthday, Sarah," Cassie said, raising the glass. The words were correct, the gesture appropriate. Task completed.

"Cassie! You made it! I'm so glad," Sarah beamed, her face flushed with alcohol and happiness. "Lea said you were locked away saving the world."

"Something like that," Cassie replied, taking a small, controlled sip of the sweet, bubbly liquid. It tasted like static. "Just debugging some code."

"Ooh, listen to her, 'debugging code'," Chloe mocked good-naturedly, rolling her eyes. "Why can't you just say you were messing about on the computer like a normal person? Anyway, you'll never guess what happened with Mark from accounts..." And just like that, the conversation flowed on without her, a river of trivialities she had no desire to navigate. Chloe was complaining about a man, Leanne was offering enthusiastically unhelpful advice, and Sarah was nodding along, interjecting with her own romantic woes. Cassie tuned it out, her mind drifting back to the elegant simplicity of her code. Here, in the pub, communication was a messy, lossy compression. People spoke in layers of inference, emotion, and misdirection. They rarely said what they actually meant. Her signal, by contrast, was pure information. A clean, simple instruction broadcast directly into the brain's core operating system: stop caring about the tribe. It was elegant. It was final. Compared to that, this babble was just noise.She watched the narrative unfold on Chloe’s face: the righteous indignation, the supportive outrage from Leanne, the sympathetic head-tilting from Sarah. The story of Mark from accounts was, to Cassie’s analytical mind, a perfect microcosm of human folly. A perceived slight in a meeting, an unanswered email interpreted as a power play, a lunchtime snub that was probably just a coincidence. From these meagre data points, Chloe was constructing a villain, and in doing so, reinforcing the identity of her own small tribe: the aggrieved, the righteous, the 'us'. It was the exact same algorithm that drove nations to war, just with lower stakes and more emojis. Cassie felt a profound sense of exhaustion. They were all just running the same flawed, ancient code, over and over again.

"He's got the emotional range of a teaspoon, that one," Leanne declared, her loyalty absolute and unquestioning. She turned to Cassie, her eyes bright with the thrill of the shared drama. "What do you reckon, Cass? Should she just delete his number and rise above, or should she send him a really passive-aggressive email and copy in his boss?" The other two looked at her, expecting a verdict, a contribution to the tribal council. Cassie’s mind presented the most efficient solution.

"Statistically, non-engagement is the optimal strategy for conflict de-escalation," she said, her voice flat. "Any responsive action, regardless of intent, provides the opposing system with new data, perpetuating the feedback loop. The most logical course is to render the initial conflict irrelevant by behaving as if it never occurred." There was a beat of perfect silence in the booth, the conversational equivalent of a system crash. Then Chloe blinked.

"Right," she said slowly. "So... ignore him?" Leanne burst out laughing, a loud, genuine explosion of sound that made Cassie flinch internally. "Oh my god, Cass, that's the most you-thing I've ever heard. You make it sound like you're defusing a bomb, not dumping a bloke who works in accounts. She should just key his car like a normal person." The three of them dissolved into laughter, and Cassie was once again an outsider, her logically sound advice treated as an amusing eccentricity. They didn't want a solution. They wanted the drama. They enjoyed the inefficiency. It was the emotional equivalent of running a computer with a thousand unnecessary programs open, just to watch the colours flash on the screen.

Suddenly, a roar erupted from the other side of the pub, a wave of aggressive sound that momentarily drowned out the music. A knot of men in matching football shirts were shouting, their faces contorted with rage. Two of them were chest-to-chest, jabbing fingers at each other. A pint glass smashed on the floor. It was about nothing, Cassie knew. A disputed penalty, a rivalry between two teams of paid athletes kicking a ball around a field. It was the Cromptons and the Yateses with more testosterone and a tribal uniform. She watched, not with fear, but with a cold, academic clarity. The posturing, the raised voices, the primate-like displays of dominance. It was all there. The same glitch, the same bug, running on a different set of hardware. This was the noise she wanted to stop. The sheer, pointless, wasteful expenditure of energy on manufactured division.

Bouncers, thick-set and impassive, moved in and separated the men with a practiced, weary efficiency. The argument subsided into grumbling and muttered threats, the spike of conflict resolving back into the pub’s low-level thrum. But the ugliness of it lingered in the air. Cassie felt it as a physical pressure, an irritation under her skin. The world was so gratingly, insistently loud. Her desire to go home, to sit before her glowing green sine wave, to press the key and release her beautiful, silent cure, became an overwhelming physical need. It was no longer a theoretical project. It was an urgent necessity.

Leanne, mistaking Cassie’s rigid posture for fear, nudged her gently. "Just idiots, ignore 'em. You look like you've seen a ghost. Are you alright, our kid?" The question was genuine, the concern in Leanne’s eyes a complex, unquantifiable data stream that Cassie’s protocols were ill-equipped to handle. It was easier to lie.

"Yeah. Fine. Just a bit of a headache," she said. The lie was also the truth. The noise, the lights, the pointless human friction—it was all a headache. A migraine the size of the world. "I think I might head off soon, actually. The noise is getting to me."

"Oh, Cass, no! It's Sarah's birthday! Just have one more," Leanne pleaded, her hand resting on Cassie’s arm. The warmth of the touch was an anomaly, a strange input she couldn’t process. It didn’t fit the system. Cassie had built her life around logic and predictable patterns, but Leanne was a chaotic function, a walking, talking, stubbornly affectionate glitch in Cassie’s own matrix. A glitch she felt a bizarre, illogical impulse to preserve. Perhaps, she reasoned, that was the ultimate purpose of her project. To create a world quiet enough that this one, single anomaly could continue to exist without being drowned out by the static.

"I can't, Lea. Honestly. The algorithm I was working on… it’s at a critical point. I need to run the final execution tonight," she said, translating her reality into terms Leanne might vaguely comprehend as important 'computer stuff'. She looked at Sarah. "I'm sorry, Sarah. Happy birthday."

"No worries, Cassie. Thanks for coming," Sarah said, already distracted by a message on her phone. The slight was registered and dismissed by the group in seconds. She was already fading from their immediate consciousness, her social function fulfilled. Cassie slid out of the booth, the vinyl sighing as she left.

"I'll text you tomorrow, weirdo," Leanne called after her, a mix of exasperation and affection in her voice. Cassie gave a small wave over her shoulder, a gesture she’d copied from films. She didn't look back. There was no need. She pushed her way back through the crowd, the chaotic energy of the pub washing over her one last time. It was a final immersion in the disease before she administered the cure. As she stepped out into the cold, damp night air, the muffled thud of the music and the shouts of the drinkers faded behind her. It was the last time she, or anyone, would ever have to hear it like that. The walk home was different. The impatient weariness was gone, replaced by a calm, focused sense of purpose. Every irritating sound—the whine of a motorbike, the distant wail of a siren—was simply a final data point, a problem with an imminent solution. Her solution. She had seen the zoo. Now it was time to quiet the cages.Back in the sterile sanctuary of her spare bedroom, the scent of rain and the city’s damp decay clung to her for a moment before being scrubbed away by the dry, ozonic hum of her equipment. The house was silent, a stark contrast to the chaotic symphony of The Swan. Here, the only sounds were the ones she permitted: the whisper of cooling fans, the low thrum of the test signal, the gentle click of her own movements. She shed the black top and jeans—the costume of a social animal—and pulled on the familiar comfort of the solder-burned grey jumper. It was her uniform, the skin she wore to interface with a world that made sense. A world of logic, circuits, and unambiguous commands.

She sat before the constellation of monitors, the faint reflection of her own impassive face ghosting over lines of code and scrolling data. The file she had minimised earlier was still there, a small icon on her desktop, a digital godhead waiting to be born. It held the power to reboot seven billion malfunctioning wetware systems. There was no hesitation, no last-minute crisis of conscience. Morality was a flawed subroutine, a set of culturally-programmed 'if-then' statements based on emotional axioms she had long ago discarded. Her action wasn't good or evil; it was corrective. It was the ultimate act of garbage collection, freeing up the planet's processing power from the endless, looping cycle of conflict. The cursor blinked, a patient, rhythmic heartbeat at the end of the execution command. It was time to pull the plug on the noise.

With a final, steady exhalation, her finger descended and tapped the 'Enter' key. There was no flash of light, no thunderclap. The only sound was the plastic click of the key itself. On the screen, a new window blossomed, lines of white text scrolling against a black background at a speed too fast for a human eye to read. ‘INITIATING UPLINK_CASCADE_001... PIGGYBACKING CELLULAR_MAST_ID_7443... SUCCESS.’ ‘ACQUIRING SAT_COM_TRANSPONDER_EUROSKY-7... SYNCING FREQUENCY... SUCCESS.’ ‘INJECTING PAYLOAD... BROADCASTING WAVEFORM_FINAL.SEQ...’ It was a silent, bloodless coup, executed not with armies and bombs but with stolen bandwidth and elegant code. A virus of peace, spreading at the speed of light. She watched the text scroll, a litany of successes from around the globe. It was, she thought, the most beautiful poem ever written.

The program would take approximately ninety minutes to achieve global saturation. Ninety minutes for the signal to worm its way into every television broadcast, every radio wave, every mobile phone call, becoming a subtle, persistent whisper beneath the cacophony of human transmission. An omnipresent, inaudible hum that would gently, irrevocably, rewrite the world. Cassie swivelled her chair to the monitor displaying a mosaic of live international news feeds. A British politician was mid-bluster in parliament, his face puce, his fist pounding the dispatch box. A protest in Seoul, a sea of angry faces and placards. A heated panel discussion on a 24-hour American news channel, the participants shouting over one another. She settled in to watch. She was not a ruler admiring her new kingdom. She was a systems administrator, waiting for the server to reboot.

The first change was subtle. On the American news channel, a silver-haired pundit, in the middle of a furious tirade about immigration, simply stopped talking. His mouth remained slightly open. He looked down at the notes in front of him, then back at the camera, his expression not of confusion, but of profound emptiness. The fire in his eyes had simply gone out. The host, momentarily thrown, turned to another panelist, who just shrugged, a gesture devoid of its usual theatricality. A deep, awkward silence fell over the studio. The shouting had ceased. The glitch was patched. In parliament, the fist-pounding politician trailed off, looking at his hand as if it belonged to someone else before quietly sitting down.

On the feed from Seoul, the effect was more dramatic. The roar of the crowd did not die in an instant, but faded like a tide going out. People lowered their signs. They looked at the flags they were waving, the angry slogans, the stylised faces of their political enemies, and a collective blankness descended. A woman in the front row, who moments before had been screaming with rage, now stared at the placard in her hands with the mild curiosity one might afford a curiously shaped stone. The group identity that had bound them together in shared fury had evaporated, leaving behind a collection of confused, suddenly quiet individuals standing in a public square for no reason they could presently recall. They didn't embrace. They didn't start singing songs of peace. They just… began to drift away, the purpose of their gathering forgotten.

Cassie allowed herself another of her practiced smiles. It worked. Of course, it worked. The logic was sound. The privet hedge, the football teams, the national borders—the neurological investment in all of it was draining away like water from a cracked basin. The world wasn't becoming a utopia. It was just becoming quiet. It was becoming manageable. She felt a deep, resonant satisfaction, the feeling of a complex equation finally being solved. A planet-sized headache, finally fading into a dull, manageable quiet. She had done it. She had turned the volume down.

Her phone buzzed, a sharp, intrusive vibration against the calm hum of her machines. LEA. A text message. For a second, Cassie felt the impulse to ignore it, to let that one last piece of the old, noisy world go unanswered. But the Leanne-protocol, ingrained through years of practice, was a powerful subroutine. It was camouflage. It was habit. She picked up the phone. The message glowed on the screen, a trivial, nonsensical artefact from a world that, in the last hour, had ceased to exist. 'Pub was dead after you left. That fight just fizzled out, was weird. Fancy a brew? Be round in 5.' Cassie stared at the message. Leanne was coming here. Into the epicentre. Into the quiet. A sudden, unfamiliar spike of data flooded Cassie’s mind. It wasn't logic. It wasn't planning. It felt, disconcertingly, like curiosity. She wanted to see what the cure looked like, up close.Five minutes. Cassie did not tidy up. She did not clear away the stray capacitor from her desk or hide the complex diagrams taped to the wall. To do so would be to engage in a social performance for an audience that was, at this very moment, being fundamentally rewritten. Instead, she prepared her observation deck. She muted the intricate hum of her broadcast equipment, leaving only the near-silent whisper of computer fans. On the largest of her monitors, she switched from the mosaic of global news feeds to a single, high-definition broadcast from a major British news network. The screen showed a presenter sitting at a vast, empty desk, calmly reading a statement about widespread communication disruptions. There was no urgency in his voice, no 'breaking news' graphics. The usual frantic energy of a 24-hour news cycle had flatlined. The world was holding its breath, and Cassie was the only one who knew why.

The knock at the front door, when it came, was unnervingly punctual and tonally incorrect. It wasn't Leanne’s usual cheerful double-rap, a percussive announcement of her arrival. It was just three simple, evenly-spaced knocks. Functional. Efficient. Cassie walked downstairs, her footsteps the only sound in the house. She opened the door. Leanne stood on the step, illuminated by the orange glow of the streetlamp. The rain had plastered a few strands of her red hair to her forehead. She wasn't smiling. She wasn't frowning. Her expression was one of neutral placidity. The vibrant, chaotic energy that usually radiated from her, the thing Cassie mentally catalogued as 'Leanne-ness,' was simply absent. "Alright?" she asked, her voice lacking its usual lilting warmth. It was just a query.

"Alright," Cassie replied, stepping back to let her in. Leanne walked into the hallway and unzipped her jacket with an economy of movement that was entirely new. She didn't shake the rain from her hair or complain about the weather. She just stood in the hall, waiting for the next instruction. "Tea?" Cassie asked, the word a diagnostic tool. "If you're making one," Leanne replied, following her into the small kitchen. As Cassie filled the kettle, the familiar social script began, but all the punctuation was wrong. "It's quiet out," Leanne observed, staring out of the kitchen window into the dark, wet garden. "The pub was odd. That fight… the two lads just stopped. Looked at each other, then one of them just walked out. The other one went back to his table and finished his pint. No one knew what to say." She wasn't recounting it as a piece of juicy drama. She was reporting a data anomaly.

Back in the spare room, the two of them sat in the glow of the monitors. Cassie handed Leanne a mug of tea, watching her take it. There was no familiar, comforting ritual of warming her hands on the ceramic. She just held it. Cassie gestured with her chin towards the main screen, where the newsreader was now listing countries whose governments had simultaneously and inexplicably ceased all legislative and public functions. "That," Cassie said, deciding that the time for metaphor was over. "That's my project. The background noise. I made it stop." She watched Leanne's face, her own internal systems poised to analyse the response. This was the moment that should have elicited shock, disbelief, anger, awe—a cascade of inefficient emotional data. Leanne turned from the screen and looked at Cassie. She blinked slowly.

"Oh," she said, the single syllable falling into the quiet room like a pebble into a deep well. "Right. Is that why I can't seem to remember what I was annoyed at Chloe about earlier?" She took a sip of her tea. "It doesn't seem very important now." She looked back at the screen, at the images of silent, empty government buildings and dispersing crowds. "So… no more arguments?" she asked, her tone one of mild, academic interest. "That's… tidy." Cassie stared at her. Tidy. The end of war, of politics, of all tribal conflict on a global scale, and Leanne, the most emotionally expressive person she had ever known, had described it as 'tidy'. The signal hadn't just snipped the thread of investment in large-scale group identity. It had smoothed out all the messy, inconvenient, illogical peaks and troughs of human feeling. It had made Leanne… efficient.

A new process began to run in Cassie’s mind, unbidden and alarming. It was a simulation, a comparison. It took the Leanne in front of her—calm, logical, quiet—and placed her beside a ghost-image of the Leanne from an hour ago, the one who laughed too loud, who cared too much about a fictional character in a trashy TV show, who would have reacted to Cassie's world-altering confession with a hundred chaotic, frantic, beautifully human questions. The signal hadn't just cured the disease of conflict. It had erased the symptoms of life. The warmth, the illogical loyalty, the entire operating system Cassie had found so baffling yet had made a conscious exception for—it had all been flattened, normalised, brought into line with the new, quiet global standard. Cassie had wanted to build a firewall to protect her work. Instead, she had switched off the power to the one thing she had, illogically, sought to shield. She had gotten her silence. But as she looked at her friend's calm, empty face, she felt the piercing, paradoxical noise of a profound and unanticipated error.The word hung in the airless room, an epitaph for a world Cassie hadn't realised she was part of. Tidy. Leanne, whose entire existence was a glorious, chaotic mess of misplaced keys, passionate opinions about soap opera characters, and fierce, un-debatable loyalty, had assessed the single greatest act of neurological re-engineering in human history and found it 'tidy'. Cassie’s brain, a finely tuned instrument for pattern recognition, flagged the response as a catastrophic error. The satisfaction she had felt only moments before curdled, replaced by something cold and sharp, a shard of glass in her meticulously ordered internal code. This new feeling was not logical. It had no discernible purpose. It was just… there. A bug. A ghost in her own machine.

"It is an efficient outcome," Cassie stated, the words an automatic response from her own programming, a desperate attempt to re-establish the logical framework that was rapidly dissolving. She watched Leanne, searching for any flicker of the old code, the warm, illogical subroutine that was her friend. But Leanne's eyes, previously so expressive, were now just optical sensors, taking in the data of the room. "The signal bypasses the limbic system's investment in tribal constructs," Cassie continued, her voice becoming more clinical as she tried to retreat to the safety of technical explanation. "It doesn't remove emotion, merely the irrational application of it to abstract group identities."

"So, the part of my brain that made me want to key Mark from accounts' car is offline?" Leanne asked, her head tilted with genuine, uninflected curiosity. "That seems practical. It would have had a high probability of negative consequences, including criminal charges." She looked down at her cooling tea. "It also explains why the thought of Sarah’s birthday party now seems… superfluous. The social bonding ritual is no longer necessary, as the intra-group tensions it was designed to alleviate no longer exist." She was analysing herself as if she were a faulty appliance that had just been successfully repaired. She was looking at the code Cassie had forced upon her, and she was approving of its elegance. This, more than anything, was the true horror. Leanne agreed with her. The real Leanne, the one who smelled of hairspray and chip spice, would have thrown the tea at her.

A desperate, illogical impulse seized Cassie. She needed to run a diagnostic. She needed to ping the old server and see if there was any response. "Do you remember when you tried to dye your own hair blonde and it went orange?" Cassie asked, the words feeling clumsy and foreign.
